title: deletion of old windows stored in memory
content:
Hello,


I have been using Firefox for many years, but I encountered a problem several months ago. I searched the same window a lot, then closed it. Since then, I have not found anything. It’s impossible to get rid of it and the more I try, the more backups of this window are made on my icon in the taskbar. I currently have 12 displayed with 46 tabs for each one. Can you tell me how to delete them? I thought about uninstalling Firefox, but that would mean losing both my bookmarks and saved passwords. I thank you very much for your help and wish you a very happy New Year. Jean-Pierre
creator: jean-pierre.bellanger

title: poslední upgrade
content:
Hmm, tuto stránku se nám nedaří najít.

K serveru na adrese idsjmk.idos.cz se nepodařilo připojit.

Pokud jste adresu zadali správně: 

   Zkuste to znovu    Zkontrolujte připojení k síti    Zkontrolujte, zda má Firefox povolený přístup na web (může být omezen firewallem).

Na každé druhé stránce se mi objeví toto hlášení, je to otravné a nedá se s firefoxem pracovat

title: Amazon Prime Movie "Downton Abbey" Says My Browser Doesn't Support HD
content:
A help page on Amazon claims Firefox can play Amazon Prime videos, yet I got a pop-up window at the beginning of the movie (not the TV series) "Downton Abbey," which I purchased in 2022, saying my browser doesn't support HD because of content. That's a paraphrase of a window that flashed on the screen and disappeared before I could take a screenshot. The window linked to a page that said Firefox browser CAN play Amazon Prime videos. So the window makes no sense to me.

Does Firefox support HD videos overall? Is there some restriction for content (whatever Amazon means by that)?

title: Flickering artifacts when watching a video on my second monitor
content:
I recently got a second monitor and I'm experiencing annoying flickering whenever I'm watching a video. It doesn't matter if the video is on my primary or secondary display. They're both the same resolution (1440p), but my main monitor is 165hz while the second is 60hz.

I've read online that disabling hardware acceleration and then re enabling it fixes this. This temporarily works for me and the artifacts disappear. But whenever I restart my PC, the issue returns and I have to disable and re enable hardware acceleration every time. How do I fix this permanently??

title: Words sticking together when using Firefox to search in browser and typing replies to emails.
content:
Hi,

I have donated to Mozilla Foundation in the past and will gladly do so again once a vexing issue has been resolved. I am using the latest Firefox version for Mac.

While using the updated Mozilla Firefox recently I find that allthewordsItypesticktogetherlikethis when I try to search for something. It can also happen when I type emails using Firefox. So I often have to change back to Safari.

Also, I notice that with the updated Firefox version, a mysterious blue square appears around the text I am working on.

Do you have any suggestions or instructions as to how to stop the annoyingjoingingtogether of words from happening? Please help!

Thankyou!

title: Firefox not accessing Windows Hosts file
content:
I asked this a year ago and never saw a solution (other than 'gee, it should work yet'.) I use the local Windows Hosts file to give my router a quick reference name to get into it. That too has worked for years but began to fail last year. Inconvenient. The best I could track this down, it has something to do with forced DNS lookups and skipping the old Hosts file. If so, any work around to get my system simplicity back? Attached is what I see on each attempt.

I tried various settings for DOH and nothing works. I can reference the Hosts file in a Windows Cmd Prompt and it resolves just fine. Something is screwy in Firefox for some time now and I'd like to know what.
